narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: 3 days/week were in person lecture and 2 days were asynchronous "in class" assignments
Virtual lecture and seminar
Asynchronous learning through textbook and online VHL
Homework, asynchronous activities, groupwork outside of class.
Live lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Significantly improved writing in Spanish and developed more confidence in speaking.
Built spanish skills
Increased reading, listening, and writing comprehension for Spanish

My overall knowledge of Spanish improved in this course, including listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. In particular, I felt I gained a large amount of grammar knowledge and practices that will help me going forward with Spanish.
I was able to improve my oral skills as well as grammatical and reading comprehension skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was adapted quite well towards the online learning format. The one weakness is that asynchronous days tended to have at least double the "in class" work as a normal day.

Cons: Just way too much work. It was unreasonable compared to my other classes, work was spread around too many different sources, several sudden video assignments were sprung on us with only a few days to complete them, and so on. It was very stressful to have multiple assignments due daily with no way to make them up. Catching up felt unrewarding and exhausting. Harsh penalties for each day late on super site made it unappealing to even try to catch up, since honestly I'm only taking this class because I have to. It felt like a punishment driving me away from ever actually getting engaged in the subject matter because small failures or outside stress snowball so quickly with this class compared to others.

Pluses would be having some asynchronous classes. This would have been impossible if class met in person each day. My professor was also kind and receptive, always very quick to reply to emails.

Could transition more smoothly into reading the book, I'd appreciate a set of vocabulary to keep in mind while reading (ie. balsa = raft). Also could have given feedback on participation and comprehension consistently throughout the semester (maybe three checkpoints through email?) so we could understand our mistakes and improve them gradually instead of being hit by the participation grade mid semester. Thank you!
The biggest strength of the course were the interactive notes and discussion in class. There weren't any weaknesses of the course that stuck out to me.
I learned a lot and improved my speaking skills but daily, there was too much work

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated not having to show up to class every day but it was difficult to have more work on the asynchronous days compared to synchronous

Asynchronous classes were good. Some remote assignments worked. Small group work really made sense for this class. However, some of the small group assignments were pretty hefty projects which were assigned abruptly. This wasn't helpful and was pretty stressful one time in particular when it was assigned several days before due, but during a week where most of us had midterms and several of us were not in the same time zone. We had normal homework (busywork honestly) and had to coordinate to complete this video assignment which was stressful. It would have been nice to have known about that requirement earlier.

Very nice and understanding on virtual platform; could have hosted optional study calls after class for people who needed a little extra help, esp considering the struggle to adapt to a virtual learning environment due to the pandemic
Synchronous classes on MWF were the best aspect of the classes that facilitated engagement.  I feel as if the course did a sufficient job of adjusting to Pandemic learning.
Less nightly assignments but the structure of the class via ZOOM was solid

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: For sure, if you need to take Spanish I would have nothing bad to say about it
No, not really. But you have to take it for the arbituary language requirement so this question is irrelevant.
Yes, I think it helped me speak spanish with more confidence
I would recommend this course to a student looking to improve their Spanish language skills, particularly in the area of grammar.
If you need it for a language requirement I would recommend it. Otherwise, it was a lot of work which made it harder to balance other classes.
